bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 165, Number 156 (Thursday, September 26, 2019)][House][Pages H8054-H8055]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. WILLIAMS:H.R. 4501.[[Page H8055]]Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1, section 8, clause 18 of the United StatesConstitution.

item.title: Consumer Transaction Account Protection Act of 2019

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

summary.text:
Consumer Transaction Account Protection Act of 2019

This bill specifies that consumer transaction account deposits of an insured depository institution shall not be considered to be funds obtained through a deposit broker. In general, current law prohibits an insured depository institution that is not well capitalized from accepting funds obtained through a deposit broker for deposit.

bill.title: Consumer Transaction Account Protection Act of 2019

item.title: Consumer Transaction Account Protection Act of 2019

To amend the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to provide that the consumer transaction account deposits of an insured depository institution are not considered to be funds obtained by or through a deposit broker, and for other purposes.
Consumer Transaction Account Protection Act of 2019

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
